Dale E Martin wrote:

>>Choose your poison, then. If you want to keep your test classes 
>>completely separate from the classes tested, then you'll only be testing 
>>the public interface (and you need to feel certain all your private 
>>methods work when they can only be tested indirectly via the public 
>>interface). If you want to test private methods directly, you must run 
>>your tests as inner classes.
>>
> 
> It is possible to rewrite the class files being tested at test-time to have
> all public methods.  Using Jakarta BCEL it wouldn't be that hard to due.
> Or you could run a special JVM that allows access to public methods.
> 
> I do realize then you'd be testing something other than the real code, but
> it's a way to get around the problem you mentioned.

Or you could write your code in a language like Python that doesn't have 
private methods. :}

Seriously, there may be other solutions (there are ALWAYS other 
solutions!), but not necessarily rational, sensible ones - or a better 
way to say it would be that they don't meet the "implicit requirements". 
I assume as a requirement that i am running in a JVM that conforms to 
Java specs - that excludes the custom JVM that ignores private. I don't 
feel i need to explicitly state such a requirement! (Then again, on the 
other hand, there are often requirements which should be explicit rather 
than implicit. I'm starting to feel like a Talmudic scholar).  Another 
implicit requirement is that the code i test be the same as the code i 
run. Frankly, i have enough problems getting the *same* code to behave 
repeatably in multiple environments! I don't want to deal with the code 
itself changing from what i tested.

Such abstract alternatives are far away from the original question, 
anyway. The problem at hand isn't even technical, but merely aesthetic - 
the poster wants to be able to keep tests in a separate package for 
aesthetic reasons, but wants to be able to test private methods from 
outside the package. That's not what private *is*!!! The very essence of 
the private method is that nothing, NOTHING outside the original class 
can access it (except for inner classes, a strange but clever hack that 
makes the outside inside). There is no way to change JUnit in order to 
accomplish this impossibility - and no need for it, since JUnit classes 
can be used as inner classes.

Conflict of technical versus technical is a problem that may or may not 
be solvable. But conflict of technical versus aesthetic is a *smell*. 
That smell says something is wrong - either not so much should be 
private, or the test harness needs to be more intimate with the code. In 
this case, aesthetics are a luxury for programmers, much like morality 
is a luxury for politicians. Sometimes we need to cast aside aesthetics 
in order to do the job correctly. Ugly but right is always better than 
pretty but wrong.
